goal: Propose a constitutional amendment to impose term limits on all members of Congress
Implement a hiring freeze on all federal employees to reduce federal workforce through attrition (exempting military, public safety, and public health)
summary: President Trump had initinally frozen hiring for some federal government workers during his first full week in office, as a way to reduce payrolls and rein in the size of the workforce. On April 12, the order was lifted.

goal: Require that for every new federal regulation, two existing regulations be eliminated
summary: On Jan. 30, Trump signed an executive order aimed at significantly cutting regulations. It requires that "for every one new regulation issued, at least two prior regulations be identified for elimination."

goal: Impose a five-year-ban on White House and congressional officials becoming lobbyists after they leave government service
summary: On Jan. 28, President Trump signed an executive order requiring appointees to sign a pledge, which says that they will not "engage in lobbying activities with respect to" their agencies within five years of leaving.

goal: Enforce a lifetime ban on White House officials lobbying on behalf of a foreign government
Ban foreign lobbyists from raising money for American elections
summary: On Jan. 28, Trump signed an executive order banning administration officials from ever lobbying the U.S. on behalf of a foreign government. political appointee joining the executive branch on or after Jan. 20 must agree to the lobbying bans.

goal: Renegotiate NAFTA or withdraw from the deal under Article 2205
summary: On April 27, Trump said he has told the leaders of Mexico and Canada that he will not pull out of the North American Free Trade Agreement at this time, but could still withdraw if he concludes a renegotiated pact is not “a fair deal for all.”

goal: Withdraw from the Trans-Pacific Partnership
summary: During his first week in office, Trump abandoned the 12-nation TransPacific Partnership brokered by former President Barack Obama. Many Washington companies participate in global trade.

goal: Direct the Secretary of the Treasury to label China a currency manipulator
summary: Backing away from a campaign pledge, President Donald Trump said on April 12 that his administration won’t label China a currency manipulator in a report due this week, though he does think the U.S. dollar “is getting too strong.”

goal: Direct the Secretary of Commerce and U.S. Trade Representative to identify all foreign trading abuses that unfairly impact American workers and direct them to use every tool under American and international law to end those abuses immediately
Lift the restrictions on the production of $50 trillion dollars' worth of job-producing American energy reserves, including shale, oil, natural gas and clean coal.
summary: On March 28, President Trump signed an order to suspend, rescind or flag for review measures to boost fossil fuel production.

goal: Allow energy infrastructure projects, like the Keystone Pipeline, to move forward
summary: Trump signed executive actions to aggressively overhaul the country's energy policy, advancing the Keystone XL and Dakota Access pipeline projects.

goal: Cancel billions in payments to U.N. climate change programs and use the money to fix America's water and environmental infrastructure
Cancel every executive action, memorandum and order issued by President Obama
Select a Supreme Court nominee
summary: In a move to replace the late Justice Antonin Scalia on the Supreme Court, Trump nominated Neil Gorsuch, who has been confirmed, to the seat on April 10.

goal: Cancel all federal funding to Sanctuary Cities
summary: Less than a month after Seattle sued President Donald Trump over his “sanctuary cities” executive order, a federal judge in San Francisco has blocked the order. Seattle will now review that ruling, which will inform the city’s next steps in its own suit, Murray said.

goal: Begin removing the more than 2 million criminal illegal immigrants from the country and cancel visas to foreign countries that won't take them back
summary: On Feb. 21, Trump signed executive actions to jumpstart construction of a U.S.-Mexico border wall and order cuts in federal grants for "sanctuary cities."The politicized term has no official definition, so it isn't clear if the administration considers Seattle a sanctuary city.

goal: Suspend immigration from terror-prone regions where vetting cannot safely occur. All vetting of people coming into our country will be considered extreme vetting
summary: In March, President Trump signed a second executive order halting the entrance of immigrants from several Muslim majority countries, this time with Iraq excluded. Like its predecessor, it was shortly struck down by a federal judge.

goal: Pass the Middle Class Tax Relief And Simplification Act
summary: On April 27, Trump proposed a tax plan with some of the same aspects promised in his original pledge to voters. It awaits Congressional approval.

goal: Pass the End The Offshoring Act
Pass the American Energy & Infrastructure Act
Pass the School Choice And Education Opportunity Act
Pass the Repeal and Replace Obamacare Act
summary: The first executive order signed by Trump aimed to repeal former President Obama's health care law. More than 200,000 King County residents are insured through the Affordable Care Act.

goal: Pass the Affordable Childcare and Eldercare Act
Pass the End Illegal Immigration Act
Pass the Restoring Community Safety Act
Pass the Restoring National Security Act
Pass the Clean up Corruption in Washington Act
